intro: Cheiranthus quadrangulus, commonly known as the four-angled wallflower, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and parts of western Asia. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes mustard and cress plants. The plant is characterized by its narrow, four-angled stems and clusters of small, yellow or orange flowers. It typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils along walls and in dry habitats. The leaves are linear to lance-shaped and often have a slightly hairy texture.
